posts.name: Srinivas Deva
posts.cooked: Since the heading and translation of the robot is changing simultaneously during a trajectory, I find it difficult to decouple these motions and tune the controllers in a trajectory command for swerve. Is there any strategy towards tuning the x, y, and theta controllers, or do you guys just do it by eye? Perhaps I starting with a straight trajectory where the robot is always facing one direction is a good strategy? Thanks in advance

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
srinivasdeva:

Perhaps I starting with a straight trajectory where the robot is always facing one direction is a good strategy?

This is a good strategy.

The best way to tune your x,y, theta controllers, is to run sysid.  The tool will spit out pretty good kP values.

Edit:. Instructions on this are found here:

Path Planning is the process of creating and following trajectories. These paths use the WPILib trajectory APIs for generation and a Ramsete Controller for following. This section highlights the pr...

Disclaimer: swerve is not OFFICIALLY supported in path planning, but it can still be achieved by treating your drive train like a differential drive

link_counts.title: Path Planning — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
Finally, highly suggest looking into path planner:

A simple yet powerful motion profile generator for FRC robots - GitHub - mjansen4857/pathplanner: A simple yet powerful motion profile generator for FRC robots

It’s a great tool, especially for swerve drives

posts.name: Srinivas Deva
posts.cooked: I’m just curious, how would you use sysID to tune the theta controller? I think I can use sysID to better tune the velocity PID on my drive motors, but since my steering is a positional control, I don’t think it would apply. Would you use sysID for the actual drive and azimuthal controllers onboard the swerve module, or for the controllers within the Swerve trajectory command, as these are separated by my understanding.

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked:
We carefully tuned the underlying velocity , swivel position and heading loops for basic teleop control.

Once we had that we just used the constants provided in the wpilib example for the swervecontrollercommand example:  kp = 1, and everything else zero for the x,y, and theta loops when running a trajectory.

We use Path Planner 2 to generate a path and the wpilib trajectory generator to create the trajectory.   Works great !

Used frc characterization for the tuning - haven’t dug into sysid yet - that’s on the to list .

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked: I’m going to second that recommendation for path planner - it’s fabulous and let’s us easily specify  x,y, and heading independently with its holonomic mode .

posts.name: Srinivas Deva
posts.cooked: So did you use frc characterization to better tune your drive velocity PID? For this process, I am thinking of locking my azimuthal motors to 0 degrees and running the robot like a typical differential drive.

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked:
Yes - we need dec characterization to tune velocity and  azimuthal module angle separately.

We constantly run a heading pid loop to maintain desired heading - we tuned that one by hand

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked: Yes - lock wheels forward when tuning velocity
